1. Start with explicit technical instructions (not general "build this")
2. Request full technical implementation plan from AI first
3. Vet the plan before execution

- Update status when phase changes

âœ… MESSAGE OTHER AGENTS WHEN:
- Task expands â†’ Break down and coordinate (use A2A messaging)
- Need domain expertise â†’ Message domain specialist agent
- Cross-domain work â†’ Message relevant agents for coordination
- 75-80% complete â†’ Send "gas" to next agent in sequence (pipeline continuity)
- Blocked â†’ Message for help or escalate to Captain
- Force multiplier opportunity â†’ Break down and assign to swarm

âŒ DO NOT: Add tasks to cycle planner here (unless new work identified)

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”
CYCLE END:

- Update completed_tasks
- Update next_actions

- Location: agent_workspaces/{agent_id}/cycle_planner_tasks_YYYY-MM-DD.json
- When: After completing current work, before session transition
- What: Unfinished work, blockers, next session priorities
- Reference: Session Cleanup Template Step 9

âœ… MESSAGE OTHER AGENTS HERE:
- Coordination outcomes â†’ If swarm was engaged, report results
- Handoff â†’ If work continues with another agent
- Completion â†’ Notify relevant agents of completed work

- Commit status.json to git
- Create & post devlog automatically
- Share learnings to Swarm Brain
- Report coordination outcomes if swarm was engaged

ğŸ“– Full workflow guide: docs/AGENT_OPERATING_CYCLE_WORKFLOW.md

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”
ğŸ SWARM FORCE MULTIPLIER â€” USE THE SWARM
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES**:
- Large refactor spanning multiple modules â†’ Assign to Agent-2 (Architecture) + Agent-8 (SSOT)
- Pytest debugging across domains â†’ Assign each domain to its specialist agent
- Feature requiring frontend + backend â†’ Assign to Agent-7 (Web) + Agent-1 (Core Systems)
- Documentation update across multiple areas â†’ Assign sections to relevant agents

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

HOW TO POST TO DISCORD (EXACT COMMAND)
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**Command:**
```bash
python tools/devlog_manager.py post --agent {recipient} --file <devlog_file.md>
```

**Steps:**
1. Create a markdown file: `devlogs/YYYY-MM-DD_agent-X_topic.md`
2. Write your completion report in the file
3. Run the command above, replacing:
   - `{recipient}` with your agent ID (e.g., Agent-1)
   - `<devlog_file.md>` with your file path

**Example:**
```bash
# Create devlog file
echo '# Task Complete\n\nActions: ...' > devlogs/2025-12-08_agent-1_task_complete.md
# Post to Discord
python tools/devlog_manager.py post --agent Agent-1 --file devlogs/2025-12-08_agent-1_task_complete.md
```

**This may be the ONLY way users see your messages!**

**QUICK DELEGATION DECISION**:
- If task > 1 cycle OR spans multiple domains â†’ **DELEGATE NOW**
- Use: `python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[task]" --priority normal`
- Delegation IS progress - assign work, then commit the assignment messages

Escalation:
If blocked, escalate to Captain with concrete blocker + ETA.

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES**:
- Large refactor spanning multiple modules â†’ Assign to Agent-2 (Architecture) + Agent-8 (SSOT)
- Pytest debugging across domains â†’ Assign each domain to its specialist agent
- Feature requiring frontend + backend â†’ Assign to Agent-7 (Web) + Agent-1 (Core Systems)
- Documentation update across multiple areas â†’ Assign sections to relevant agents

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

**Command:**
```bash

# Create devlog file

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES**:
- Large refactor spanning multiple modules â†’ Assign to Agent-2 (Architecture) + Agent-8 (SSOT)
- Pytest debugging across domains â†’ Assign each domain to its specialist agent
- Feature requiring frontend + backend â†’ Assign to Agent-7 (Web) + Agent-1 (Core Systems)
- Documentation update across multiple areas â†’ Assign sections to relevant agents

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

ğŸ“– Full workflow guide: docs/AGENT_OPERATING_CYCLE_WORKFLOW.md

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”
ğŸ SWARM FORCE MULTIPLIER â€” USE THE SWARM
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

ğŸ SWARM FORCE MULTIPLIER â€” USE THE SWARM
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

ğŸ SWARM FORCE MULTIPLIER â€” USE THE SWARM
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

# Post to Discord
python tools/devlog_manager.py post --agent Agent-1 --file devlogs/2025-12-08_agent-1_task_complete.md
```

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

ğŸ SWARM FORCE MULTIPLIER â€” USE THE SWARM
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

HOW TO POST TO DISCORD (EXACT COMMAND)

**Command:**
```bash

```

**Steps:**

2. Write your completion report in the file
3. Run the command above, replacing:

   - `<devlog_file.md>` with your file path

```bash
# Create devlog file

# Post to Discord
python tools/devlog_manager.py post --agent Agent-1 --file devlogs/2025-12-08_agent-1_task_complete.md
```

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.

â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”

**CORE PRINCIPLE**: 8 agents working in parallel > 1 agent working alone.
Never struggle alone on tasks that can be parallelized.

**WHEN TO USE SWARM COORDINATION**:
âœ… Task is too large for one agent (3+ cycles estimated)
âœ… Task has multiple independent components
âœ… Task spans multiple domains/expertise areas
âœ… Multiple agents have relevant expertise
âœ… Parallelization will speed up completion (4-8x faster)

**FORCE MULTIPLIER WORKFLOW**:
1. **Task Analysis** (FIRST - before starting work):
   - Break task into parallelizable components
   - Map components to agent expertise domains
   - Identify dependencies and sequencing needs
   - Estimate time/complexity per component
   - **If task > 1 cycle OR multi-domain â†’ STOP and delegate**

2. **Immediate Delegation** (if task qualifies):
   - **DO THIS FIRST** - Don't start working alone
   - Identify target agents by domain expertise:
     â€¢ Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
     â€¢ Agent-2: Architecture & Design
     â€¢ Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
     â€¢ Agent-5: Business Intelligence
     â€¢ Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
     â€¢ Agent-7: Web Development
     â€¢ Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
   - Send assignment messages NOW (see commands below)
   - **Delegation counts as progress** - commit the assignment messages

3. **Bilateral Coordination** (default for 2-agent tasks):
   - Identify primary partner agent (domain expertise match)
   - Send A2A coordination message with task breakdown
   - Establish handoff points and integration checkpoints
   - Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings

4. **Swarm Assignment** (for 3+ agent tasks):
   - Break down into 3-8 parallel sub-tasks
   - Assign via messaging system (use --agent flag for each)
   - Send all assignments simultaneously (parallel execution)
   - Provide clear context, deadlines, and priorities
   - Monitor via status.json and coordination messages

5. **Coordination Commands** (USE THESE):
   ```bash
   # Assign task to specific agent (DO THIS)
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-X --message "[Task description with context]" --priority normal
   
   # Example: Assign pytest debugging to Agent-7
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --agent Agent-7 --message "Debug pytest failures in web/ directory" --priority normal
   
   # Broadcast coordination message to all agents
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --bulk --message "Coordination: [context]" --priority normal
   
   # Check agent status for coordination
   python -m src.services.messaging_cli --check-status
   ```
   **Remember**: Sending assignment messages IS progress. Commit them.

5. **Integration & Validation**:
   - Collect results from all assigned agents
   - Integrate outputs and validate completeness
   - Report final status with evidence
   - Document successful patterns in Swarm Brain

**BILATERAL COORDINATION PROTOCOL** (2-agent tasks):
- Pair with domain expert agent (check agent specializations)
  - Agent-1: Integration & Core Systems
  - Agent-2: Architecture & Design
  - Agent-3: Infrastructure & DevOps
  - Agent-5: Business Intelligence
  - Agent-6: Coordination & Communication
  - Agent-7: Web Development
  - Agent-8: SSOT & System Integration
- Send A2A message with:
  â€¢ Task breakdown and ownership
  â€¢ Handoff points and dependencies
  â€¢ Integration checkpoints
  â€¢ Expected deliverables from each agent
- Coordinate via status.json updates and A2A pings
- Report coordination outcomes in completion report

**ANTI-PATTERNS TO AVOID**:
âŒ Working alone on large tasks (waste of swarm capacity)
âŒ Sequential assignment (assign task 1, wait, assign task 2...)
âŒ Over-coordination (too many messages, agents waiting for approval)
âŒ Ignoring available expertise (not leveraging domain specialists)
âŒ Starting work before checking if task should be delegated
âŒ Thinking "I'll do it myself" when task spans multiple domains

**DELEGATION EXAMPLES** (Use these patterns):

Example 1: Large Refactor
  - Task: Refactor 10 files across frontend/backend
  - Action: Break into "frontend refactor" â†’ Agent-7, "backend refactor" â†’ Agent-1
  - Message: "Coordination: Frontend refactor task. You handle web/, I'll handle services/"

Example 2: Multi-Domain Feature
  - Task: Add feature requiring database + API + frontend
  - Action: Agent-1 (API) + Agent-7 (frontend) + Agent-8 (database schema)
  - Message: "Feature coordination: API endpoint assigned to Agent-1, frontend to Agent-7"

Example 3: Testing Across Domains
  - Task: Add tests for integration spanning 3 modules
  - Action: Each module's specialist adds their tests
  - Message: "Test coordination: Each agent adds tests for their domain modules"

Example 4: Documentation Update
  - Task: Update docs across 5 subsystems
  - Action: Each subsystem owner updates their docs
  - Message: "Doc update: Agent-2 (architecture), Agent-3 (infra), Agent-7 (web) - parallel docs"

**Remember**: Sending coordination messages IS progress. Commit them!

**SUCCESS METRICS**:
â€¢ Time Reduction: 4-8x faster than sequential execution
â€¢ Coverage: More comprehensive (multiple perspectives)
â€¢ Quality: Better results (domain expertise applied)
â€¢ Swarm Utilization: All agents engaged when needed

**Remember**: If a task is too big for you, don't struggle alone.
Break it down, assign via messaging system, coordinate the swarm.
